In order to meet the growing demand and ensure the safety of transportation, a total of 317 kilometers of main railway lines have been overhauled in Azerbaijan according to the state program on the development of railways in 2010-2014. A project currently being upgraded is the signaling and communication systems, which is underway now. Naturally, the increased transit volume of oil and oil products will generate greater revenues for the railway system.

To what extent is your institution seeking to interconnect the railway network with ports and roads to facilitate the transportation of goods?

At a time when intermodal transportation has become widespread, the railway administration has been doing consistent work to keep pace. The construction of the Baku International Trade Seaport has begun an on area of 400 hectares in Alat. The port will play a pivotal role in handling transit goods proceeding along the East-West and North-South international transport corridors and in receiving and transporting key goods required by the national economy. The construction of the new port will be carried out in three stages. The completion of the first stage will enable the transportation of up to 10 million tons of cargo and 40,000 TEUs. The second phase will facilitate the transportation of up to 17 million tons of cargo and 150,000 TEUs, while the third phase will provide for the transportation of up to 25 million tons of cargo and 1 million TEUs. The construction of the first stage of the port is scheduled for completion in July 2014. Therefore, in light of the fact that up to 25 million tons of cargo will be processed by the Baku International Trade Seaport in the near future, work is now underway to expand the throughput capacity of the Alat and Yeni Alat stations. Talks regarding the design of the stations are currently under way with the relevant government agencies. The commissioning of the Baku International Trade Seaport provides an impetus to the development of the associated railway infrastructure.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Dmitriy Solovyov graduated from the Ukrainian State Maritime Technical University in 1998 and commenced his international career in the field of logistics and supply chain management joining headquarter of SunTea Group of Companies in Dubai, UAE. He then moved to the field of hydrocarbons transportation, joining in 2001 Middle East Petroleum FZE, a company that became operator of Dubendi Oil Terminal. He joined Ocean Energy in 2003, a company actively engaged in oil trading in the Caspian and Black Sea regions. He joined Cross Caspian Oil & Gas Logistics, a company whose majority shareholder is the State Oil Company of the Azerbaijan Republic (SOCAR), in 2006 as Planning and Logistics Department Manager.
node.title: On the Rails
node.richbody0content:
How do you expect the recent signing of the Shah Deniz final investment decision to impact the logistics sector and Cross Caspian?

While the impact of this decision on Cross Caspian is hard to assess at this point in time, it comes as great news for the entire sector and for the country in so much as it will open up opportunities to export large volumes of condensate to Black Sea ports. It is also a marked achievement by the key players of the energy sector in Azerbaijan as the sector will continue to develop and attract interest and investments. Further expertise in the energy sector will be developed and, what is more, Azerbaijan will contribute to securing energy stability for international markets in the long run. In that sense, it is a significant achievement for all stakeholders.

The Baku-Tbilisi-Kars (BTK) rail project is shortly to be completed. Are you looking to include it in your network?

In terms of logistics, the greater the diversification, the more opportunities for shipment you can offer. In other words, in any region intending to transport significant volumes of commodities, the development of a hub is crucial so that you can offer inward and outward shipment in numerous directions. This project is therefore a great opportunity to diversify and extend our reach via rail. At the same time, it is possible for us to encourage inward shipments, which could provide much interest and the necessary structures to handle inflows of cargo from Kazakhstan. We are mostly an oil and gas transportation company, but do also look attentively at developments in dry cargo as this is a related market, and the two industries affect each other. Azerbaijan is increasingly becoming a regional leader in terms of its transportation and logistics infrastructure.

How have Cross Caspian's operations developed in recent years?

We aim for sustainable growth, and therefore pursue gradual expansion. We are now in the process of completing the first phase of a terminal that exports some of the Shah Deniz condensate, a project that began back in 2008. We are working on interconnections with the terminal, and the facility is shaping up well. We are also working to acquire additional private railcars. The corridor itself has around 4,000 rail cars, but we are working on bringing in newer ones. We work in the private sphere; of those 4,000, around 1,500 are private freight stock and we are working to bring in a further 1,000. There is the feeling that in the long run, a modern system should be managed by private companies. In 2013, the capacity of the corridor was at between 12 million and 14 million tons by rail. The cargo overhaul for hydrocarbons was at around 10 million tons for the year. A significant volume of crude oil was shipped via BTC to the BTC entry point, which is understandable given that the BTC is a unique asset and very well placed geographically. It is a high-quality and modern pipeline managed by leading companies. Azerbaijan is an extremely stable and visionary player in the region, which attracts shippers, and ultimately the BTC provides very good returns to those who invest. That is why when considering the transit figures, you should combine the BTC transit figures with those of rail. We have increased our volume significantly, and the total volume of BTC transit exceeded 5 million tons. When you combine figures shipped via rail and through the BTC, overall we note good progress. It was tough work because we were taking on a few things for the first time, such as delivering different grades into the same pipeline at the same delivery point. It is quite an efficient arrangement both technically and commercially.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Haji Ibrahim Nehramli was born in 1958, and graduated from the Economics Faculty of Nakhichevan State University. In newly independent Azerbaijan, he established Ilkan in 1991. Between 1995 and 2000, he was a Deputy of the Supreme Majlis of Nakhichevan, and also founded Avesta Concern in 1996. He is currently the President of the company.
node.title: Reclaimed Land Ahoy
node.richbody0content:
What progress has been made on the Khazar Islands project?

Construction efforts on the Khazar Islands project started three years ago, and will be conducted in four stages, the first of which is expected to be completed in 2014. In recent months, we have built a restaurant complex, a four-kilometer long boulevard, beaches, and entry gates to the project, as well as a sports complex, and have laid out parks. We are planning to inaugurate our first restaurant complex, the Stingray, on May 28, 2014, the national day of Azerbaijan, which is an important accomplishment for us as we have worked hard on this project. Over the next two years, we are planning to complete more construction and carry out several opening ceremonies, as well as hand over keys in residential schemes. The deadline for completing the entire complex is 2030.

What would you say are the key logistical aspects of the project and how are you addressing them?

Our priority is to employ the latest technologies and most durable materials in our project in meeting high international standards. The safety and comfort of our customers is key to what we do. For that reason, we will not be using any cement in the project, but rather will rely on marble and stone that we procure ourselves. Another important aspect is to ensure our staff is comprised of highly skilled employees through a thorough interview and selection process. We now have a team of over 3,000 professionals. Thirdly, securing funding is an important consideration that we address through negotiations with foreign investors, both abroad and at home, to familiarize them with the project. These efforts will all contribute to the development of future partnerships.

You are about to launch the sales campaign for the 12 residential buildings already completed. What customer base are you targeting?

We are open to both local and foreign customers, which we hope to welcome with attractive financing options such as mortgages without down payments and interest-free loans.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Babak Babayev was born in Nakhichevan in 1970 and worked until 2001 in the private sector in Moscow. In 2002, he returned to Azerbaijan and established Yeni Hayat.
node.title: All Involved
node.richbody0content:
What were Yeni Hayat's most important projects in 2013?

Yeni Hayat Group started operating in 2002, and ever since the first day our main guiding principle has been customer satisfaction. Our residential complexes, shopping, and entertainment centers fully comply with the wishes and needs of the customers in terms of their price-quality ratio. Yeni Hayat Group is one of the leading companies in Azerbaijan's construction market from the standpoint of quality, location, design, and complexity. Yeni Hayat has built some of the architectural and construction gems of Baku, such as the Yeni Hayat Residence, Yeni Hayat Plaza, and the Azure Complex, which comprises the Azure Residence, Azure Business Center, and MegaFun entertainment center.

In light of the company's extensive experience in residential construction, what characterizes Yeni Hayat's residential concept?

One of the key contributors to the success of the Yeni Hayat Group has been its approach to customers' needs and expectations. Before embarking on any project, we try to identify what customers in this particular market segment tend to expect and require. At the construction stage, we provide even higher quality than the customer may expect. In addition to the above, we remain committed to this approach at the selling stage and try to provide the best possible value for people's money.

Yeni Hayat is recognized for its support of Azerbaijani sports, and the Olympic team in particular. Seeing how the country will host the first edition of the European Games in 2015, what are your plans in this area?

The inaugural European Games will be held in Baku in 2015 and will be held once every four years thereafter. I want to emphasize that it is our duty as an Azerbaijani company to contribute to the development of our country in any sphere. Our interest in and support for the Olympic team stems from our confidence in our athletes. We believe that our sportsmen will successfully represent our country and raise our national flag. We as Yeni Hayat Group feel proud of our athletes and are always ready to support the national team.

What projects are you planning for 2014-2015?

The ongoing construction of the Park Azure residential complex is expected to be completed by September 2015. Furthermore, the Grand Hayat complex, which offers customers innovative designs, will also be inaugurated in this period. For 2014, we have also planned the inauguration of one of our most ambitious projects, namely Hayat Palace.

President Aliyev was voted in for a third term in office last year. What do you expect this third term to bring for the real estate sector?

Over the past several years Azerbaijan has become one of the fastest growing nations across the globe. The economy has grown 3.4 times. Some of the primary reasons for that are the reforms under way in the country, stability, and public order. Of course, this stability is a product of President Ilham Aliyev's activities. It has also created favorable conditions for the economic development of Azerbaijan. The President has always been very supportive of private enterprise development, and we are confident that this support will continue to be provided in the interests of further dynamic development of our country.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Hasan Yalçınkaya was born in 1966 in Turkey and graduated from Boğaziçi University in Istanbul in 1993 having studied Mechanical Engineering. Between 1995 and 2002, he worked as a Project Engineer and then as project Manager in the Istanbul and Paris branches of Lafarge Ciments. Between 2002 and 2008, he was Project Manager at Yibitaş Lafarge and Cimpor Yibitaş Groups, then becoming General Manager of the Hasanoğlan Cement Plant, owned by Cimpor Yibitaş, in 2009. In 2011 he joined Norm Cement.
node.title: Built to Last
node.richbody0content:
How did Norm perform over 2013?

It was a very busy year, being the last phase of our project. We did our best to complete the cement plant and get production underway. In September, we successfully commenced cement production at our plant, and in October, after ensuring the quality of our product, we started to market it. Over the course of 2014, we expect to increase the range of grades and achieve full production capacity.

What led to the establishment of Norm?

The construction industry in Azerbaijan is one of the fastest growing industries today. It has become one of the driving forces of the country's economic development. A growing need increased the investments aimed at cement production and stimulated Norm to implement the Norm Cement plant project. When the company was established, Azerbaijan was importing 65% of its cement needs either in direct cement or clinker form. In the cement industry, clinker is a core input. Once you produce clinker, you can grind it into cement or else sell it directly as a product. Currently, the installed capacity of Azerbaijan can meet just 35% of demand, meaning that 65% was imported from neighboring countries, mainly Iran. This was one of the driving forces behind our construction of the plant. Another driving force was to bring up the quality of cement in Azerbaijan.

What are the special features of the plant?

The Norm Cement plant is the largest cement plant in the South Caucasus. The capacity of plant is 5,000 tons of clinker per day and 2 million tons of cement a year. The plant, constructed in the Garadagh district of Baku, is designed according to the most advanced European technology. The main process equipment of the plant is supplied from leading manufacturers in Germany, France, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and other EU countries. The cutting-edge technologies and equipment will ensure high quality, safety, and efficiency, as well as minimize fuel and power consumption while preserving the most stringent European and global ecological standards. The project, one of the largest in terms of investments in the non-oil sector, will cost $350 million and provide immense social and economic benefits.

What measures are taken for environmental protection?

In the cement industry the biggest pollution comes from dust emission. The proper control of dust emissions requires significant investment in technology and environmental protection equipment. At the Norm Cement plant, the entire production line is equipped with modern dust filters. Air quality is continuously monitored by the optical measuring devices installed in all sources of dust according to the strictest standards. The allowable dust emission by EU standards is 35 mg per cubic meter, while filters installed at our plant ensure 30 mg/cubic meter or less. The plant is equipped with a strict noise protection system to comply with another EU standard of 85 dB maximum noise at 1 meter from the source. The application of the latest technologies ensures the operation of the plant in accordance with European and international environmental norms.

What sectors account for the bulk of your portfolio?

In Azerbaijan, there is roughly an equal three-way distribution between residential, infrastructure, and non-residential construction. A total of 4.5 million tons of cement is consumed in Azerbaijan. We want to be present in all the segments of the cement market, including infrastructure, residential, and non-residential. By the end of 2014, we will have a large portfolio of products targeted at all cement segments. The Norm Cement plant will also supply the oil industry of Azerbaijan and of the whole Caspian region with oil-well cement that complies with the standards of the American Petroleum Institute. We will start producing this type of cement for the oil industry at the beginning of 2015.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Pablo Trujillo Tealdo is an Economist and Founding Partner of Acción Fiduciaria and Action Trust. He has extensive knowledge in the trust market, and is an expert in strategy, finance, and economics with 32 years of experience in the financial sector. He is also Co-founder of the Skandia Trust and Founding Partner of the Alianza Trust, as well as its CEO for 16 years. He has served as President of the Colombia Trust Association Asofiduciarias, and of the Latin-American Trust Association Colafi.
node.previewsummary: "The return an investor can expect from the real estate sector naturally enough depends on the level of risk they assume."
node.title: Evaluate This
node.richbody0content:
How has the volume of assets under management (AUM) in Colombia's fiduciary sector changed over the past few years?

When one uses AUM to assess the development of the sector, one must understand that it is possible to have a high volume of AUM with a very low turnover. For this reason, it is better to talk about commissions, the number of operations you manage, and the volume. Thus, AUM is a good tool to evaluate the fund management sector. The trustee sector experienced a very interesting trend in 2013; the volume of operations rose, but at the same time income volume fell. That was due to a loss in the net asset value (NAV) of funds experienced last March, after which many people retrieved their investments. At the same time, there was a crisis of sorts in the entire public trustee segment. Therefore, we saw a very important reduction in commissions from the public segment, as well as those from fund management. In this context, we are a trustee firm with slightly different processes, and 2013 was a very good one for us in terms of growth and profit. The sector tends to be much more linked to the fund management segment, whereas we have a higher participation in the trustee line.

What type of trustee companies can foreign investors find in Colombia?

It depends very much on the type of business investors want to focus on. For example, if they target infrastructure, then they should look for a trustee bank, as they have a wide knowledge of the sector and impressive capacities. However, if the business requires management operations, then it would be better to resort to an independent trustee company. I think it is also important to keep in mind the location of the trustee firm, as this is key to knowing in which area you want to focus your activity.

“The return an investor can expect from the real estate sector naturally enough depends on the level of risk they assume."

How significant is the real estate business for the company's overall activity?

We enjoy a strong position in the real estate market. The real estate sector brings together certain elements that are key for us, such as being able to target diverse investor types, from very small to multinational, depending on the stage of each project. This sector also enables us to manage operations and activities with different risk profiles. Our role is to facilitate a constructor's access to different markets. We are an independent trustee firm that has the capability to access the market in different ways and target different types of investors. Our clients have a long-term vision and aim to hold assets for a long time period, meaning less rotation and speculation.

What is the potential of the Colombian real estate sector when it comes to attracting foreign investors?

The return an investor can expect from the real estate sector naturally enough depends on the level of risk they assume. Having said that, Colombia is a very attractive market with high growth levels; unemployment levels are on the decline, which brings more people with purchasing power to the market, fuelling the urban reconstruction that many cities are undergoing.

What impact does the governments' regulatory reform have on Colombia's asset management sector?

The asset management industry is mainly a fixed-income market, as the country has historically suffered from high levels of inflation. At the same time, other markets, such as derivatives, are only in their infancy. The evolution of this industry will be linked to large investors. Regarding the reform, it has barely just come into force, and we should keep in mind that it was developed with special attention to those companies that aim to become active industry players. Nevertheless, I do believe we will begin to see new and more specialized products reaching the market.

What projects have you been most proud of?

We are especially proud of the fiduciary rights-based projects we have developed over the years at Acción Fiduciaria—in other words, those popularly known as crowd funding. Thanks to groups of small investors, we have been able to carry out many large projects that have become very important for the history of Colombia.

What's the strategic reason behind your expansion to Panama?

To put it simply, we wanted to become a bilingual company, and expand our activities; we had many projects priced in Colombian pesos and realized that we needed to expand to markets that use the US dollar. Colombia still has some bureaucratic barriers when it comes to dealing with US dollar-based projects. We see Panama as a country that can help us attract further small international investors and showcase Colombia's developments to the world.

Where do you see Acción Fiduciaria in five years time?

Our priorities for the next few years include developing new markets for investors interested in fiduciary rights-based projects; also, as the public-private partnership (PPP) model becomes more popular, trustee companies will have the challenge of providing solutions to investors. We also believe that private banking will become widely common over the next few years and perceive considerable potential there.

How can the trustee industry benefit from the Pacific Alliance?

It is a very interesting initiative, because, apart from Chile, the remaining countries have a trustee industry that is very much institutionalized. I think there's a potential for trustee networks between countries and common alliances to benefit regional clients. We should be able to develop a common regulatory framework to better attract investors. The concept is suitable for countries operating similar economic models, and the road ahead is promising, if challenging.

Would Europe be an interesting market for Acción Fiduciaria to expand its activities to?

We are currently holding talks to try to show our European counterparts in Spain and Italy the benefits of the Latin American model. Chief among them is its greater flexibility when it comes to tackling financial crises that would render them much more dynamic in their current conditions, especially as these economies advance on the road toward recovery.

© The Business Year - June 2014

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Joseph Carasso began his career as a Management Associate for Banco Citibank in Brazil in 1997, and subsequently served in a number of positions for Citi Brazil. He began his international career in 2002 as Senior RM and Country Representative Officer for Angola and has also worked in senior positions in Uganda. He is currently the Managing Director of Citibank Tanzania. He has a degree in Business Administration from Candidio Mendes University in Brazil as well as an MBA in Finance from IBMEC.
node.previewsummary: "The long-term strategy is to be able to service this market as it matures."
node.title: Paradise City
node.richbody0content:
What role does Tanzania play in Citibank's global strategy?

Tanzania is an important market for Citibank in terms of the manner in which we have expanded from the outset. Globally we are a 201-year-old establishment, and from the early days our expansion and footprint has followed industry trends and client needs. As our clients became regional and global, we too have expanded into those same geographies to cater to their requirements. We have had a presence in Africa for almost 100 years. Tanzania presents a very unique combination of opportunities to our clients, stemming from its size, with nearly 50 million inhabitants, its geographic location bordering eight countries, its economic diversity and stability, and its political maturity. And, with sustained GDP growth of 7% for the last 10 years, and prospects of even faster growth in the future underpinned by new industries coming on stream, reforms, and integration in the East Africa Community, among other factors, the country should become even more important to Citi over time.

How does Citibank leverage its international reach to improve its services in Tanzania?

What really makes us unique is the fact that we leverage our global platforms, products, and infrastructure so as to offer the same banking experience wherever we operate. Combined with our global footprint and reach we have local on-the-ground knowledge, which allows us to offer our clients the best possible solutions. Subject to local regulations, we are able to bring our global services and products to our clients, which is a real advantage. It also allows us to leverage investment in new products, infrastructure, technology, and security.

“The long-term strategy is to be able to service this market as it matures."

How does Citibank view the rapidly rising mobile money trend in Tanzania?

Whilst Citibank's focus is on institutional banking, we see the rising mobile money trend as an opportunity that is about using technology as a means of servicing our clients from a transaction banking perspective. Furthermore, there is the aspect of financial inclusion. Although we do not play directly to the consumer side of banking in this market, we have done so indirectly through our involvement in mobile banking as we have been a key player in this sector from its inception. Citibank was at the forefront of developing technological solutions for mobile operators and also of playing a role in terms of dialogue between operators and regulators to take things where they are today, in both Tanzania and Kenya. For us, mobile money is about technology that allows for greater financial inclusion through the provision of a cost-effective means of payment to individuals, as well as an alternative payment/collection channel for our institutional clients.

Citibank is currently being consulted by the government in preparation for its debut Eurobond offering. How does risk assessment here differ from other African countries?

Citibank does not perform risk assessments in the context of rating advisory, but we do assist governments in preparing for the due diligence that rating agencies perform. We help sovereigns to prepare their presentation to the rating agencies, and to articulate and discuss their stories in a balanced and efficient manner. It is important to make this distinction. In terms of how Tanzania compares with other countries, there are rules and regulations in place governing activities in the international capital markets that preclude us from discussing this matter in detail, and the process in Tanzania is still in its early stages, but we believe it will not materially differ from other African and emerging markets countries, once it gets going.

What milestones do you hope to reach by the end of 2015?

Specifically, we would like to have sustained double-digit growth, principally by focusing on improving our client experience, keeping the highest standards of ethics, rigorous controls, and performance management. We want to continue to invest in our people, providing growth opportunities to our Tanzanian staff. We want to simplify our structure without compromising on controls (in fact increasing them), improving our efficiency and our client experience.

You have been here for 18 years. Where do you see Citibank in the next 18 years?

The long-term strategy is to be able to service this market as it matures to be able to continue to play a role in the growth of the financial sector and the community. We will continue to be a responsible player in the market and hope to continue to be perceived as an institution that adds value to the country, that supports our international and domestic clients, the government, and the banks, and that contributes to Tanzania's development and future. By doing so, we intend to meet our corporate and growth objectives. Ours is a long-term commitment. We are a stakeholder in the country and we have a bias toward the country's continued success.

© The Business Year - June 2014

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Anar Mammadov was born in 1981 and attended American Intercontinental University in London graduating with Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees in Business Administration. Mammadov has been working with ZQAN Group since 2005, and guided its rebranding as Garant Holding.
node.title: Hold the Fort
node.richbody0content:
How would you evaluate Garant Holding's performance in 2013?

I am happy to say that 2013 was one of the most successful and productive years in our history. We rebranded the holding with a name more readily understandable in many languages and quickly associated with the various companies that operate under the corporate umbrella. Taking on this new name has galvanized our sense of responsibility and stimulated new initiatives and projects. We are the only holding in Azerbaijan to have been recognized by PricewaterhouseCoopers, and have received ISO 9001:2008 certification from TÜV AUSTRIA Hellas, the International Certification Organization. Another highlight of 2013 was the opening of the luxury Rixos hotel in Guba, a pivotal region in Azerbaijan. By completing such projects, we are contributing to the state program for the social and economic development of other provinces in Azerbaijan through tourism facilities. The project is of considerable importance to the holding, but also to Guba, as it has improved infrastructure, involved local residents, and provided employment.

What is the focus of Garant's construction segment?

A major success in recent years was our efficient and rapid completion of the Trump Tower project. The challenge that we embraced was to ensure that the style of the building was consistent with the surrounding architecture in Baku, and that the project was sustainable. The main challenge that we are facing now is to promote Baku effectively in the international arena. Meanwhile, the construction arm of Garant continues to work on several large-scale projects.

In which areas is the agribusiness branch of Garant engaged?

Garant has leveraged the success of its financial branch to diversify, having directed its efforts toward the production and manufacturing of food products. One of the initial steps we have taken in this field is the establishment of Ucar Agro LLC, named after the area in which it is based. This time, we have also remained true to the principle of the development of rural regions of Azerbaijan, employing our best people to ensure success. There are many companies engaged in poultry production, but with demand from local consumers being high we have channeled innovative technologies to meet it, resulting in the introduction of a new brand of poultry product. Our poultry processing operation has an annual production capacity of 17 million (live weight) tons with a cutting rate of 6,000 chickens per hour; it will produce fresh and frozen poultry, whole and sliced. The enterprise is valuable and of great importance in providing employment in rural communities. Overall, 590 workers have been involved directly in our production processes, and 150 people have been engaged in related fields of the enterprise.

“ Azerbaijan is a country with a range of available opportunities and conditions for the development of entrepreneurship. "

This year has seen the start to the third term in office for President Aliyev. What will this mean for the business community?

Azerbaijan is a country with a range of available opportunities and conditions for the development of entrepreneurship. We have the opportunity to operate effectively due to the care and attention of President Ilham Aliyev. As the President has stated, the growth of entrepreneurship in towns and regions will ensure successful national development. He has underlined the need to pursue a liberal economy to this end. In recent years, through the sensible use of incoming exchange reserves from the sale of oil resources, the government has achieved the advantageous base required for the dynamic development of sectors of the economy relevant to strategic, diversified business structures and the development of the broader economy. The generation of oil revenues has contributed to this development and played a pivotal role in the formation and establishment of developmental tendencies within economic and social sectors. Of course, those engaged in entrepreneurial activity will be entering a more large-scale activity phase in large part owing to this productive environment.

As the founder of the Azerbaijan America Alliance, how do you evaluate the importance of this bilateral relationship for the country's economic development?

The Azerbaijan America Alliance is a non-political, non-profit organization the main goal of which is to deliver broad information regarding the culture, history, way of life, and lifestyle of the country. The Alliance's mission also includes the provision and building of mutual understanding and fostering mutual respect between American and Azerbaijani people. The alliance has arranged successful projects through academic dialogue, cultural programs, and political debates in the US over the span of several years. Our outreach campaign to create awareness of the Khojaly massacre in the US forms a major part of the goals of the alliance, and we have been attempting to convey the importance of this tragedy and crime against humanity to officials there, in order to foster a better understanding of our region's unique geopolitical realities. This program has been focused on informing people in Washington, DC and New York, in order to achieve a high-impact message. My hope is that the Alliance's cultural, political, and economic relations will play an important role in strengthening and promoting more productive and favorable relations.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Ahadpur Khangah was born in Tehran in 1952 and graduated from university in the UK specializing in engineering and road construction. Between 1975 and 1986, he worked in road construction for a family-owned business in Iran, and later worked on projects including the modernization of the Iranian Social Club in Dubai. He has lived in Azerbaijan since 1993 and is currently Chairman of the Az Group of Companies.
node.title: Renaissance Man
node.richbody0content:
How is Az Group looking to increase its industrial production in 2014, the Year of Industry, in Azerbaijan?

In 2013, AZFCO, the dairy production enterprise of the group, succeeded in becoming certified by the US Army to supply US soldiers in Afghanistan with dairy products. There are expansion plans for 2014 to add new cheese, butter, and ice cream lines to the plant. Today, the plant produces a diversity of dairy goods, including 67 varieties of yogurt, milk, probiotic yogurts, and ice creams. Our industrial products are even reaching international markets. AZ Plas, the group's packaging factory, exports to Georgia, whereas AZMDF exports MDF and parquet laminate flooring to Georgia, Iran, and Turkmenistan. The expansion plan for AZMDF 2014 is to add a brand new production line for doors, windows, and kitchen cabinets.

Moving to the automotive sector, what led Az Group to commence truck assembly in Azerbaijan?

Az Group was the first exclusive Isuzu dealer in Azerbaijan. After a while, when Isuzu saw our capability with regard to the automotive industry, it suggested building an assembly line in the region. We reached agreement on how this was to be achieved, and currently the plant is under construction and our first prototype will emerge by February 2015. Today, we are the only company in Azerbaijan that will assemble light and heavy trucks locally. Meanwhile, we opted to assemble Isuzu's models because it is the best truck brand in the world.

How will you go about training the workforce for this assembly plant?

We are going to send Azerbaijani technicians to Japan and other assembly lines around the world for training. Meanwhile, Isuzu Japan has suggested that we work with the Isuzu assembly plant in order to train our local technicians.

“ Our target is to release 50 million fingerlings per year into the Caspian Sea by 2020. "

Az Group is also working to build an English language school. What can you tell us about this project?

The school that AzEdu, Az Group's educational arm, is building, will be managed and operated by GEMS International, which is the largest private education company worldwide. It will be advising us on how to set up an International Baccalaureate curriculum, which will encompass the US and UK educational systems. The school will be able to accommodate 2,500 students and will be open to expatriates and Azerbaijanis who wish to enroll their children in an English language school. Azerbaijani students who wish to attend university, college, or boarding school abroad will also benefit from this system. The school will make an international education system that meets global standards available to Azerbaijani parents. Therefore, being able to provide a solid education locally, many parents will be spared the separation of sending their children abroad.

Can you provide some key metrics for AZ Group?

Aztikintiyol manages and runs the production of aggregate and asphalt in the country. It started operations in 2008 with two regional plants, and, since then, we have opened six further plants around the country for these products. Our production capacity has increased, and we can produce 2,400 tons of asphalt per hour, or 57,600 tons of asphalt and 72,000 tons of aggregate per day. By our estimation, this is enough to cover every project in Azerbaijan in 2014. Aztikinti, another company that produces concrete, can produce 1.2 million cubic meters of concrete per year, which would cover 35% of total Azerbaijani demand. AzSole was the first industrial plant of Az Group, and was established in 2006 to provide steel for infrastructure projects. Its initial capacity was 1,000 tons per month, whereas in 2012 it reached a capacity of 3,500 tons per month. We always set ambitious targets that help us to grow.

What have been the developments at Caspian Fish, Az Group's sturgeon farm?

The farm has in excess of 36,000 sturgeon set to start producing caviar this summer. The current total volume of our fish is approximately 96 tons, which will increase to approximately 400 tons by this summer, when temperatures rise. Also in the summer of 2014, we will see our first dispatch of 2 million fingerlings into the sea. We will also be inviting scientists from Geneva to inspect the farm and make their own estimation of the volume of fish there so that we can obtain a quota for caviar exports. The quota given is normally 10% of the weight of the fish at a farm. Hopefully, for 2015, the quota will make available approximately 30 tons to 40 tons of caviar for export and internal use. Our target is to release 50 million fingerlings per year into the Caspian Sea by 2020, so that future generations can also enjoy wild caviar.

Lastly, what are Az Group's social initiatives?

Independently of Az Group, I operate the Azerbaijan Animal Rescue Center (AARC), which was founded in 2008 and situated in the center of the city. Subsequently, having decided that our animals needed a much quieter space, we transformed a six-hectare property that was formerly a hotel into a modern and sophisticated animal shelter. Additionally, AzTexnika, our automotive company, sponsored the G3 City Challenge in Baku in 2012. Due to the success of this event, we also sponsored the G3 World Final in October 2013. In September, we organized the event “Polo Returns Home" to celebrate the sport of polo, which originated in Azerbaijan thousands of years ago and was later adopted by the British.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Fazil Mammadov studied at the faculty of Finance and Credit in the Azerbaijan State Economic University. From 1987 to 1989, he worked as an economist in the Ganja and Baku Industrial and Construction banks. Later, he served as a lecturer and chair head at the Finance and Credit College before going on to work at Unsal and Agro-Industrial banks, and as head of the Main Department for Finance, Tariff, and Currency Control of the State Customs Committee. In 1999, he was appointed Chief of the Main State Tax Inspection. He has been the Minister of Taxes of Azerbaijan since 2000.
node.title: Checks and Balances
node.richbody0content:
How would you assess the performance of the Ministry of Taxes in terms of achievements in 2013?

The achievements of the Ministry of Taxes are based on the results of the country's economic development. The effective economic strategy implemented in Azerbaijan over the past decade has turned the country into one of the fastest growing economies, with GDP increasing more than three-fold. The country achieved overall economic growth of 5.8% in 2013, and an increase of 10% in the non-oil sector. Today, Azerbaijan accounts for 73.6% of the economy of the South Caucasus. This is, of course, a major factor in determining the dynamics of tax revenues, as well as the provision of tax services. At the Ministry, we are satisfied with our progress in 2013, a year characterized by both the fulfillment of fiscal tasks and the modernization of tax services and administration. In 2013, taxpayers were offered services based wholly on the latest international standards. Following discussions with the business community, we launched partnership relationships with taxpayers in 2013. Amendments were also made to tax legislation to specify frameworks for partnership agreements. We have already seen the signing of the first agreements. Entrepreneurs show considerable interest in this issue, and it will remain one of the key activities of 2014. Meanwhile, measures such as introducing electronic audits, addressing tax risks, and reducing tax debts are further examples of the successes of 2013.

How does the government use the tax policy to stimulate economic diversification and investment in priority areas?

All countries extracting natural resources, including Azerbaijan, are challenged by the problem of economic diversification. It is of utmost importance to ensure that the economy is safe and the domestic market is protected from varying impacts from the world market. Each state seeks to raise the competitiveness of its economy to ensure sustainable development. The economic course of Azerbaijan run by the President of Azerbaijan, Ilham Aliyev, aims at building an economy based on the development of the non-oil sector and the introduction of high-level technologies. The Azerbaijan 2020: Outlook for the Future development concept is an indicator of the resolute actions taken by the government in this direction. The concept specifies in the mid-term perspective the following: forming a diverse, efficient, and innovation-oriented economy; turning Azerbaijan into a regional investment hub; achieving development in the social sector; ensuring the welfare of people at an internationally accepted level; and developing scientific, cultural, and social life. It is a widespread international practice to make use of tax policy to stimulate economic growth, which is particularly distinctive for developing countries with low tax loads. We call this an active tax policy. The introduction of tax privileges with the consideration of fiscal loads in tax policy is becoming a widely applied practice in the key development areas in Azerbaijan. Agriculture, one of the key sectors comprising GDP, has long been practically exempted from tax, which undoubtedly contributed to development of the agrarian sector. Ilham Aliyev, the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan, has declared 2014 the Year of Industry. A range of works is being carried out to establish techno-parks, which will likely play a major role in the formation of new areas in the national economy and making them competitive. In this manner, to stimulate the development of industrial parks and techno-parks in the mid- and long-term perspectives, legal and natural entities operating at such parks enjoy tax exemptions for a period of seven years, whereas the managing organizations and operators of these parks are exempt from taxes for an unlimited period.

What is the role of the tax policy regarding the promotion of the use of renewable energy?

The State Program on the Use of Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources in the Republic of Azerbaijan approved by Order No. 462 of the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan on October 21, 2004, is a key document in this area. In accordance with Paragraph 3 of the Plan of Action for the Use of Alternative Energy Sources, the Ministry of Taxes, to stimulate the use of alternative energy sources and create a favorable investment climate, has proposed specific amendments to relevant legislation to exempt raw materials and equipment imported for production purposes from VAT.

“At present, 91% of tax declarations submitted by taxpayers to the Ministry of Taxes are submitted electronically. "

What are the most important changes in the simplification of the tax system?

Reforms in the area of tax services envisage the fulfillment of several significant duties to be addressed within the national system. First, the tax system must be stable and predictable. Second, the tax administration has to be convenient and favorable to the greatest extent possible. Third, the stimulation of the role of the tax system in forming the structure of the economy and supporting innovations must show more progress. Finally, the tax system and its administration in Azerbaijan need to be more competitive. The tax system has to be simple and favorable for businesses, competitive and efficient for the state, and manageable for tax services from the point of view of administration. These are the key principles followed in all tax reforms. The Ministry of Taxes has achieved a considerable reduction in officeholder-citizen contacts by continuing the application of electronic services in all spheres of tax administration. The latest electronic technologies are used to facilitate the contact of taxpayers with the tax authorities, from registration to the submission of declarations, and from the payment of taxes to tax control. Doing Business 2014 included Azerbaijan in its top 10 list of countries to have successfully carried out reforms regarding the starting up of businesses. Reforms in 2011 and 2012 in the area of the state registration of entrepreneurship entities, particularly in the digitized registration of citizens and legal entities by electronic means, are some of the main reasons for this favorable reputation. The number of procedures and the time required to register a business in Azerbaijan is less than the average indicators of OECD members, as well as Eastern European and Central Asian countries. In addition, the average time spent on the completion and submission of tax declarations, as well as compliance with legislative norms for the payment of taxes, is relatively better than the average statistics of Central Asian and Eastern European countries and the world in general. At present, 91% of tax declarations submitted by taxpayers to the Ministry of Taxes are sent electronically. By continuing the digitization of tax services and introducing new services, we are likely to achieve impressive progress.

The government declared 2013 the Year of ICT. How did your organization benefit from its achievements?

The introduction of information and communication technologies in the national tax service is an important development. President Ilham Aliyev declared 2013 the Year of ICT, which gave an additional incentive to further accelerate and broaden related efforts. “ASAN Imza," or Mobile ID, was one of the projects initiated by the national tax service within the Year of ICT. ASAN Imza, in combination with the creation of a security system, has helped users to display their digital identity via mobile phones. To ensure its effective operation, the new Certification Services Center for electronic signatures has been set up in the Ministry of Taxes, which was integrated with the Mobile ID center established by an international consortium with the participation of companies from France, Sweden, Estonia, and Azerbaijan. Since the Center was established in compliance with European standards, it created the possibility for the mutual recognition of electronic signatures with European countries, which has created a favorable environment for Azerbaijani citizens when establishing joint ventures with citizens of other countries and signing agreements electronically online. The new system allows the use of electronic signatures for all devices, including computers, tablets, and smartphones. Notwithstanding the short period, some 24,000 Mobile ID certificates have been issued to its holders across 2,000,000 transactions. Today, the Mobile ID project is not just a tax service, but a national brand offered as an original product. This project came about as a joint effort with our Estonian colleagues, and fully meets all the quality and security parameters required for mobile IDs in Europe. In February 2014, the Mobile ID was presented as an original Azerbaijani product to the European Parliament in Brussels. It is also worth noting that the Mobile ID is a competitive and export-oriented product of Azerbaijan. Currently, several countries are closely interested in this project. During the Year of ICT, the Ministry of Taxes extended the scope of electronic services, and currently offers taxpayers 51 electronic services.

How will the 2014 reduction in the amount of transfers from the State Oil Fund (SOFAZ) to the state budget affect the operation of your organization and tax collections?

In a meeting of the Cabinet of Ministers held in 2010 and following the main development directions of 2011, President Ilham Aliyev tasked the relevant government bodies with ensuring that revenues collected by the Ministry of Taxes and other authorities are sufficient to cover public budget expenditures, and that transfers from SOFAZ shall be spent only on investment projects. At present, this is a strategic necessity for the key target areas of the national tax service. We have observed a 55.2% increase in tax revenues over the past three years. Increases in revenues in the non-oil sector reached 59.7%. In general, the growth rate of tax revenues in the non-oil sector exceeds the growth rate of GDP in this field. In the past three years, growth in non-oil GDP constituted 9.4% in 2011, 9.7% in 2012, and 10% in 2013, whereas the volume of non-oil revenues reached 21.9% in 2011, and 14.5% in 2012 and 2013. To put it another way, the level of increase in non-oil revenues exceeded the real increase of GDP in the non-oil sector by 2.3 times in 2011, 1.5 times in 2012, and 1.4 times in 2013. This tendency gives us reason to believe that we must continue the process of discovering new potential taxation bases and applying efficient tax control measures. The share of the non-oil sector in overall tax revenues is projected to reach 60.5% in 2014.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Elman Rustamov started his career in 1973 at the USSR State Planning Committee, later becoming Chief Councilor at the Presidential Office of the Republic of Azerbaijan. In 1992, he became the First Deputy Chairman of the Management Board of the National Bank of Azerbaijan, and later rose to become Chairman. In April 2000 he was appointed Governor of the Central Bank of Azerbaijan and is currently serving his third term.
node.title: Far & Wide
node.richbody0content:
What was the contribution of the Central Bank of Azerbaijan (CBAR) to the economic accomplishments of 2013?

Last year was particularly successful for the Azerbaijani economy, where growth, primarily driven by the non-oil sector, exceeded average global and CIS growth rates. Moreover, the actively pursued diversification policy boosted the share of the non-oil sector in GDP, and the country maintained macroeconomic stability amid dynamic growth. Despite double-digit growth in the non-oil sector and high investment demand, average annual inflation in 2013 was at a low 2.4%. Azerbaijan's international ratings further improved to this backdrop. In the World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Report, Azerbaijan rose seven positions to 39th place. It also rose by 10 positions to eighth in the world in terms of macroeconomic stability and sustainability. As the institution tasked with doing so, the CBAR succeeded in maintaining macroeconomic stability, the key prerequisite of balanced economic growth, utilizing the stabilizing and promotional capacity of the monetary policy in light of the economic environment. In parallel, the CBAR introduced flexible financial stability management tools to regulate risks and prevent overheating in the banking sector. And to contribute to economic diversification, the CBAR was actively involved in the implementation of the government's economic policy, promoting financial deepening of the banking sector, and the development of financial infrastructure.

The CBAR decided to postpone the rise in minimum capital requirements for banks by one year. What factors informed this decision?

The reason why we raised the capital requirement was to deepen financial intermediation, elevate service quality, adjust to capitalization-related global challenges, and enhance the sector's financial sustainability. The decision was also made as part of the banking sector's long-run growth concept. The sector enjoys a high potential to harmonize to the process. Today, the capital of 23 banks owning 84% of banking sector assets exceeds AZN50 billion. The CBAR supervises banks' capitalization on an ongoing basis aided by a critical support for banks. A number of banks have already unveiled their capitalization plans to the public. The process will be problem free both for the sector and consumers, as in previous periods. The banking system's capital adequacy ratio (CAR) reached 17.3% on three percentage point growth YoY. The ratio exceeds international standards two fold and the CBAR threshold by five percentage points. This performance demonstrates the banking sector's attractiveness for investment, as well as its reliability, financial stability, sustainability, and capacity to successfully adapt to the new capital requirements. The new capitalization level markedly widened the banks' potential to credit the economy, as well as service the real sector and the population alike. In parallel, it will play a large part in reducing the cost of banking services and products through high competition and a scale effect in the banking sector. Given the above, and other banks' high capitalization potential, as well as the ability to secure funds of bank creditors and depositors and protect the sector's overall financial stability, the Management Board of the CBAR extended the capital adjustment period from November 14, 2013 until January 1, 2015.

How would you evaluate the soundness of the Azerbaijani banking sector?

Sustained stability and growth are prevalent in the Azerbaijani banking system. Between 2003 and 2013, sector assets rose by a factor of 20, while the credit portfolio grew by a factor of 23, and deposits 17 fold. Soviet-era deposits have been recovered at the most favorable conditions observed anywhere in the CIS community. The banking sector had remained stable and trustworthy even during the global economic crisis. Foreign exchange and capital flows have been liberalized in the country. And, in general, we expect the new capital requirements of banks to underpin the implementation of the Basel III accord. We have been successfully applying the leverage ratio—one of the key protective instruments of Basel III—in Azerbaijan since 2011. Moreover, the CBAR has already made corrections to, and is applying relevant regulations, within the framework of improving banking capital structure and quality. The CBAR is also focused on banking sector liquidity. We have evaluated options to introduce two new tools recommended by the Basel Committee. Although the liquidity coverage ratio is in essence similar to the instant liquidity ratio currently applied in Azerbaijan, that is to say, it targets a short-run liquidity regulation, it is a more complex and advanced tool. We have diagnosed the ratio in question and discussed its application prospects in the banking sector. The CBAR now plans to apply this ratio as a normative requirement in the coming period. As for the net stable funding ratio, the tool is being globally debated and needs to be tested. The CBAR has decided to review this ratio in the coming periods, too, given its possible negative impact on the balance between financial stability and long-term economic growth-financing policies. In 2014, the macro- and micro-prudential policy will be oriented toward the management of overheating in the banking system via systemic regulation and individual supervision to ensure financial stability. The Basel III standards will be tailored to the local environment, and the development of counter-cyclical banking supervision continued.

“Between 2003 and 2013, sector assets rose by a factor of 20, while the credit portfolio grew by a factor of 23, and deposits 17 fold. "

What role can the CBAR play in enhancing financial inclusion, and how would the latter contribute to economic growth?

Naturally, financial inclusion is generally among the key factors in ensuring the inclusiveness of economic growth. The prerequisite here is to expand access to financial resources and high-quality financial services. The CBAR is currently taking the necessary stimulating measures to increase the financial deepening of the banking sector. Increased financial deepening directly serves to expand the available credit resources in the economy. In this sphere, necessary measures oriented at stimulating increased cashless settlements were taken over 2013. Likewise, a number of regulative and policy measures were taken in order to facilitate the reduction of interest rates. Particular attention has been paid to increasing the banking sector's activity in the regions and in the non-oil economy. The development of microfinance and rural banking is amongst the priorities for us. The expansion of financial-banking infrastructure, the institutional development of the financial-banking sector, and increasing the efficiency of financial intermediation serve to strengthening financial inclusion as well. Ultimately, the CBAR's activities are oriented at the flexible transformation of reserves accumulated in the economy to economic growth, mobilizing them through the banking sector. This will provide access to additional investment resources for businesses, and enable the population to further improve their living standards, enjoying financial services.

In late 2013, President Ilham Aliyev won a third sweeping victory at the polls. What do you expect his third term to bring in terms of economic growth and monetary stability?

We are fairly optimistic with respect to economic growth in Azerbaijan in the coming five years. This optimism is due to the strong economic achievements of the past 10 years and the new economic strategy underway. Azerbaijan has entered the league of medium-income countries following the explosive growth witnessed over the past decade. Both the Azerbaijani government and international organizations predict a stable and dynamic growth pattern for the Azerbaijani economy in the medium term. As such, the country's ratings are improving faster than ever, thus boosting investor confidence in the economy. Azerbaijan has become one of the most attractive investment destinations for the financial sector. The new strategic growth course targets constant growth of the national income through the shaping of diversification, export-oriented growth, knowledge, and innovation, which will pave the way to new, quality, high growth rates for the national economy. The CBAR is working to maintain macroeconomic stability and the international competitiveness of the non-oil economy, contributing to low-level inflation. At the same time, the banking sector will be promoted far and wide to make a great figure in the full-blast capitalization of the non-oil economy. It will continuously undergo structural reforms to that end.

node.author: TBY
node.title: Making a Mark
node.richbody0content:
Could you give a brief description about the new sales activities carried out by Audi in Azerbaijan?

It has been approximately two years since our company, European Cars Ltd, became the official distributor of Audi in Azerbaijan. Public interest has always been high for Audi products during this period of time. From the first day, our aims were to place this brand in its rightful place and increase the reputation of these cars once they were in Azerbaijan. This goal has been achieved by the implementation of Audi-specific market policy, which includes providing high-end after-sales service to our customers. The organization of proper after-sales service is an answer to many questions about our success. Audi is a premium brand, and this makes it vital that we offer a premium service at a reasonable price in all criteria of our work.

What improvements has Audi made for the sake of increasing its market share in 2013, and what achievements do you expect in 2014?

We will do our best in order to steadily increase our customer base. In addition, we are planning on starting the construction of the new Audi Terminal, which will include a showroom and after-sales area all in one location. This facility will offer a variety of services and will be more convenient for Audi customers in the long run.

What differentiates Audi from other high-quality car brands in Azerbaijan?

Audi models have always been ahead of their competitors in terms of dynamic handling. Audi applies the technology used in racing cars into daily road vehicles, which, in the long run, makes the cars more dynamic, durable, and safe. In collaboration with all these features, Audi models are efficient consumers of fuel in comparison to the competition. Also, they can adapt to different road conditions thanks to the multilink suspension system. Audi Exclusive offers a wide range of individual options for customers who want to experience the difference. The Audi Exclusive program offers a variety of leather options and different types of natural wooden décors for the interior, as well as technical advantages that standard production vehicles do not have. Audi has another major advantage over its competitors, which is called the quattro all-wheel-drive system. The biggest advantage of quattro is that this system is completely mechanical and does not depend on any sensors or clutches like its competitors. The quattro system is just as effective on smooth roads as it is in bad road conditions.

How did you deal with the competition between auto dealers in Azerbaijan?

Before entering a competitive market, it is essential to research the specific demand for a given product, which later brings us to the point of preparing a proposal based on the findings. Today, we offer highly competitive products in accordance with the findings that we witnessed from our market research.

How has the country's economic development benefited the local auto market?

The economic development of a country is equivalent to the improved financial status of its citizens, and this will definitely play a positive role in the success of the automobile business, which is the pulse of the modern world in all areas of social life.

Ilham Aliyev was elected as President for the third time in 2013. How do you think this new era will affect the automotive industry?

The magnificent victory in the elections of our President Ilham Aliyev is a symbol of development, prosperity, and success, as well as a victory for the luxury lifestyle sector. Luxury lifestyle means having access to luxury cars, such as Audi, and we believe that it will be a positive.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Göksel Aybek was born in 1950 and is a graduate of the Faculty of Engineering at Erciyes University in Turkey, majoring in Mechanical Engineering. He has 37 years of experience as a Director and Member of the Board for several large Turkish firms before joining Akkord in 2012.
node.title: Major Projects
node.richbody0content:
What were last year's accomplishments for Akkord?

Overall, 2013 was a challenging but, at the same time, successful year for Akkord Corporation in terms of sustainability. We have overcome all the challenges we faced through innovative thinking. The company has implemented some major projects on a national scale, including launching the first production line of the Gazakh Cement Plant, opening a multi-level, tunnel-type road junction in Galaba (Victory) Square in Baku, and signing a contract for the construction of a new Khatai Hazi Aslanov-2 section of the Baku Metro Green Line. These three large-scale projects became milestones for Akkord Corporation as it constantly strives to extend the frontiers of its activities. The company has also managed to break down stereotypes associated with its image as a solely construction-oriented company. It is noteworthy that launching the Gazakh Cement Plant comes in line with the implementation of the State Program for the Social and Economic Development of the Regions of the Republic of Azerbaijan for 2009-2013, as it plays an important role in the socioeconomic development of both the Gazakh region and the country as a whole. Besides satisfying domestic cement demand, we are aiming to expand our global cement production footprint and become a regionally competitive cement producer. In addition to these achievements, in April 2013, Akkord Corporation was awarded Best Enterprise in the Field of Construction in the South Caucasus and Central Asia by the Institute of Directors at the Europe Business Assembly in London. Later that year, the company became a corporate affiliate member of the International Tunnelling and Underground Space Association (ITA-AITES) and World Road Association (PIARC). Akkord Corporation is the first and only private company from the South Caucasus that is affiliated to these highly reputable organizations.

How is the Baku Metro project progressing?

As for the Baku Metro project, metro tunneling and underground construction is a new business line for Akkord. A long-term conceptual development scheme for the Baku Metro that was prepared following a Presidential decree of November 10, 2008, and the State Program for the Development of the Baku Metro in 2011-2015, approved by a Presidential decree on March 18, 2011, has laid the groundwork for the Metro's expansion plans. To contribute to the program, Akkord Corporation has entered into a partnership with France's Bouygues Travaux Publics, which is one of the largest global experts in underground work. The contract, signed on December 16, 2013, has crowned our two-year joint efforts to develop the construction project for a new Khatai-Azi Aslanov-2 section of the “Green Line." In the future, we anticipate concluding more similar contracts, as the Metro development plan stipulates the construction of additional 50 stations. The company continuously develops its expertise in this area, so it could be involved in other relevant projects around the country.

What major undertakings are underway in 2014?

Being not only a construction enterprise, but also a production and investment company, Akkord Corporation nowadays continues to invest heavily in the production and processing of building materials. The company's orientation to the country's manufacturing sector comes in line with President Ilham Aliyev's socio-economic development program for 2014-2018. The Head of State restated that the development of the non-oil sector remains Azerbaijan's top priority in the economic sphere this year and has declared 2014 the Year of Industry. As a leading building materials supplier, Akkord Corporation aims to support the President's decision and will continue to produce cement, concrete and concrete precasts, asphalt, marble, granite, steel structures, gravel, sand, bricks, and other materials not only for our own needs, but also for the wider market in Azerbaijan. This will be possible due to 40 manufacturing and processing facilities that the corporation owns and operates throughout the country. These facilities are located close to raw material sources and project sites, which allows us to enhance production efficiency and optimize project costs. We also have plans to increase the production of building materials, including fiber concrete, at our pre-fabrication plant. This year, such new entities as Gazakh Cement Plant, Akkord Prefabrik (precast concrete plant), Akkord Beton, and Garadag Marble and Granite Plant will commence operations within the Industry Group set by Akkord Corporation this February. Through heavy investments into industry and manufacturing, pioneering the application of new technologies and know-how, Akkord Corporation is making a substantial contribution to the development of the country's production sector and will adhere closely to this line of work. Besides that, Akkord Corporation has passed the pre-qualification stage to bid for the Trans-Anatolian Gas Pipeline (TANAP) project, and we plan to continue participating in tenders under this and Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) proj­ects. The internationally recognized brand that Akkord Corporation has managed to build over the years enables the company to contribute to these projects, which will have profound impact on the world energy marketplace. I would like to stress that we are focused on bridging all the areas of our activity and building a sustainable business model. The scale of investment reflects Akkord Corporation's policy of vertical integration, and this policy and investment in production facilities that it requires will continue this year.

What projects is Akkord working on abroad?

Currently, Akkord Corporation has a very strong presence not only in Azerbaijan but also in several foreign markets including Turkey, Germany, Albania, Georgia, Russia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and Ukraine. The success of our international projects is largely based on cooperation with leading construction and engineering companies through different forms of partnership. The corporation has reached agreements with some globally renowned companies, such as Hochtief and Bouguyes Travaux Publics, our partners in the joint venture for the Baku Metro project. Recently, the Azerbaijan-Italian Akkord-Todini-Impregilo Joint Venture has won the tender to implement road construction works under the CAREC III Corridor, Shymkent-Tashkent Project in Kazakhstan. Akkord Corporation has been participating in the Western Europe-Western China International Transit Corridor project since 2010. In total, the Corporation is implementing tens of high-complexity large infrastructure projects across the Caspian-Black Sea region.

How important are human resources to Akkord?

As one of the major employers in Azerbaijan, Akkord Corporation contributes significantly to the formation of a positive work environment and corporate culture. The corporation considers human capital as its most important asset to maintaining sustainable growth, and is doing its utmost to attract, retain, inspire, and motivate people working in the company. Nowadays, more than 4,000 employees including specialists from the UK, Germany, Italy, France, Portugal, Ukraine, Bangladesh, Russia, Georgia, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Iran, and Turkey are involved in daily operations domestically and abroad, and the key objective for us is to have right motivation tools and to offer various benefits to enable them to perform at their best. The company is constantly striving to balance the needs of the business with its employees' expectations. We believe that all our employees add value to our business, and their contribution to our common success does not go unnoticed or remain undervalued. Thus, this year Akkord Corporation is starting an initiative to congratulate hundreds of employees working in the company for five years or more to recognize and praise their loyalty to the company and work for its prosperity. Akkord Corporation is investing heavily in manpower and is widely reputed as a company employing highly qualified personnel in every country where it operates. We are keen to deviate from a common practice in the construction sector to work with sub-contractors, because we believe that developing and training our own employees will be more beneficial in the long run when it comes to building a highly successful business, not only in profit, but also in culture.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Prior to PASHA Bank, Farid Akhundov held various managerial positions including Head of Financial Control Department, Head of Customer Services Department, and Area Compliance Office for HSBC Azerbaijan, and Deputy CEO at the HSBC Bank of the Middle East. In addition, he arranged the restructuring and rebranding of Most Bank, Azerbaijan to Bank Standard JSC. He was also Director of F.T.F MMC Consulting Company. He received his degree with honors in Economics from the Azerbaijan Economics Institute in Baku. He completed the Management Course of Nottingham Trent University in 1993, and received an MBA from the University of Salford in Manchester. Farid Akhundov joined PASHA Bank in 2007 as Chairman of the Executive Board.
node.title: Regional Roots
node.richbody0content:
How would you describe PASHA Bank's performance in 2013?

Overall, 2013 represented a new phase of institution-building for PASHA Bank, following the initial process that took place at the time of our foundation in 2007. We accomplished numerous “firsts" during 2013, such as the first club loan, which we implemented in collaboration with a group of international financial intuitions. We have received high ratings from international rating agencies; in fact, the highest among Azerbaijani private banks with 100% local capital. In 2013, we also expanded our operations and appeal to the market. For the first time in our history, we started appealing directly to international institutional investors invited on road shows held abroad, which helped promote PASHA Bank as a gateway to Azerbaijan for financial institutions and investors. We are one of the most active banks in the securities market in Azerbaijan, and we trade government securities and are involved in a number of bond issues. We have issued bonds for several financial institutions and leasing companies. In terms of results, we ended the year with a profit, although slightly behind the budgeted figure we had planned for ourselves. The overall dynamics of the YoY growth have been positive. We are the only financial institution in Azerbaijan that makes its forecasts public—this reflects the level of confidence and transparency to which we adhere.

What services does the new SME Business Center provide to enhance the SME experience at PASHA Bank?

Investments in the SME sector are an integral part of our growth strategy. We want the SMEs of today to grow into the large corporates of tomorrow. In 2011, we started developing this strategy and building a relevant client base. In 2012 and 2013, we conducted a number of SME campaigns and, starting from 2013, we began building up a portfolio of small clients. In order to ensure that we are close to our SME clients, we opened our first Business Banking Center in 2013, which renders services to small companies that employ about 10-15 people and have an annual turnover of between AZN200,000 and AZN2 million. We plan to open more centers in 2014 in the belief that SMEs will play an important role in our future business. PASHA Bank offers its clients an internet banking platform to render banking easier and more accessible. In fact, the bank has developed a whole range of innovative banking products, while offering other value-added services that will contribute to the financial and institutional growth of SMEs. Although we are not a retail bank, we are prepared to look after our SMEs both in terms of their business and personal financial needs.

What updates are being planned for PASHA Bank's internet platform?

Thanks to the internet banking platform that we launched two years ago, the volume of our transactions has increased and many of our corporate clients have embraced this service. Our branches remain busy, and the platform is still small compared to some European or North American banks; however, this simply represents a growth opportunity for us. Over half of our highly active corporate clients have adopted internet banking within the past 18 months. We are now planning a second update to our platform to make it even more tailored to customers' needs. Obviously though, direct banking solutions will remain important for corporate clients. In 2014, we will be implementing both MIS and CRM systems. We are also working on our treasury management system with one of the world's top IT solutions companies. In 2014, we will be introducing Phase II of our credit management model. We have made substantial investments in IT in order to increase service standards and operational efficiency. Technology saves clients' time, which is an important asset. However, as a bank that values relationships with customers, we are keen to strike the right balance between technology and personalized attention.

“ In order to ensure that we are close to our SME clients, we opened our first Business Banking Center in 2013. "

What does the bank's corporate social responsibility (CSR) platform consist of?

As a company that has adopted corporate governance principles, we recognize the community as one of our stakeholders; therefore, we keep it in our books, minds, and hearts. One of our CSR mandates fosters economic development by investing in human capital and financial education. Therefore, our CSR is mostly aimed at educational programs. We identify talented young students and send them to prestigious business schools abroad. We have also established a PASHA Bank scholarship for the students of economic universities; therefore they can have sufficient resources to work on their education, buy the books they need, and have fewer financial worries so that they concentrate more on their studies. PASHA Bank also supports business case study competitions between young economists aged between 18 and 22 years old, which helps to foster a culture of entrepreneurship. In tandem with the British Council, the bank has been organizing financial journalism courses for Azerbaijani journalists. Experienced specialists from the Thomson Reuters Foundation teach Azerbaijani journalists how to read economic data and write financial news. It is possible to earn money responsibly, and we believe we have struck the right balance in doing just that. Going forward, we believe that approach will support our ambition to grow returns on our social investments as well. It is a long-term plan, and this is exactly why we are doing this—we are not here for short-term profit.

How has the Georgian subsidiary of PASHA Bank performed to date, and what new markets are you looking at?

It is actually doing better than we had budgeted for, and we celebrated its first anniversary on January 17, 2014. I believe that Georgia will be an important, integral part of our regional operations. We are a regional bank with an aspiration to become a financial gateway on the “regional triangle" between Baku, Tbilisi, and Istanbul. The Azerbaijani banking system is very young, and hardly any bank, except for the International Bank of Azerbaijan, has expanded into international markets. Going forward, on the back of our regional international ambitions, we will be proud in the future to have developed further international operations to announce.

How can banking sector penetration be increased?

Azerbaijan's relatively low banking penetration rate constitutes in itself an opportunity for growth. The potential for the market is huge, and we believe we can grow significantly in Azerbaijan. Things are changing fast and, over the past 10 years, we have seen huge growth in savings as Azerbaijanis have become more educated about, and trusting of, the banking system.

What are your aspirations for PASHA Bank in 2014?

Our aspirations are in step with national goals because as a responsible corporate citizen, we respect our roots. At the same time, we have roots in Georgia and expect to take root in Turkey as well. Our ambition is to become a regional bank capable of diversifying its client and asset base across the region, and benefiting from regional growth and international trade. We want to increase our market share in all our markets, but particularly in Azerbaijan, which will be helped by the new strategy for 2015-2017.
